citation.article-title: Legionella quinlevanii sp. nov. isolated from water.

p.s: Description of Legionella quinlivanii sp. nov.
Legionella quinlivanii (quin.liv.an'i. i. L. gen. n. quinlivanii of Quinlivan)
Legionella quinlivanii is a Gram-negative rod with a single polar flagellum; L. quinlivanii grows on BCYE agar but not on media lacking L-cysteine.
It is positive in tests for catalase and gelatinase and produces a brown, diffusible pigment on tyrosine-yeast extract agar.
It is negative in reactions for oxidase, urease, hippurate hydrolysis Î²-lactamase, nitrate reduction, and acid production from D-glucose.
It is serologically distinct from other described legionellae and can be identified with the slide agglutination test.
The G + C content of DNA from the type strain is 43 mol%.
All strains contain predominantly branched-chain cellular fatty acids.
The type strain of L. quinlivanii is 1442-AUS-E (ATCC 43830).
It was isolated from water in South Australia on 10 March 1986.
